definition: to procrastinate/to stall for time/to filibuster
to drag/to tow/to trail/to hang down/to mop (the floor)/to delay/to drag on
surname Yan
to prolong/to extend/to delay
o'clock/time/when/hour/season/period
surname Shi
between/among/within a definite time or space/room/section of a room or lateral space between two pairs of pillars/classifier for rooms
gap/to separate/to thin out (seedlings)/to sow discontent

sentences.english: I can't permit you to temporize any longer.
sentences.chinese: 我不能允許你再拖延時間了。

sentences.english: People often use several well-known excuses to procrastinate.
sentences.chinese: 人們經常用一些人所共知的藉口去拖延時間。

sentences.english: The opposition suspects Mr. Saleh's talk of stepping down is just an attempt to stall for time.
sentences.chinese: 反對方猜想薩利赫先生的講話只是爲了拖延時間。

sentences.english: One year, the losing side managed to drop the ball in a well to bide time.
sentences.chinese: 有一年，失敗方曾設法把球投到一口井裏來拖延時間。

sentences.english: The intervention would buy time for diplomacy to work.
sentences.chinese: 這種干涉是爲了有成效的外交而拖延時間。

sentences.english: He stalled for time to wait for his friends coming.
sentences.chinese: 他拖延時間等着他的朋友的到來。

sentences.english: The speaker temporized in order to delay the vote.
sentences.chinese: 這個演講者拖延時間以便拖延選舉。

sentences.english: I was stalling for time to guess the correct answer.
sentences.chinese: 我開始拖延時間來猜測正確答案。

sentences.english: I don’t kill time or procrastinate with TV.
sentences.chinese: 我從來不用電視消磨時間或拖延時間。

sentences.english: They were widely criticized for feigning injuries to stop the clock.
sentences.chinese: 他們因爲在球場上假裝受傷拖延時間而受到廣泛批評。

definition: variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
the trick of injuring oneself to gain the enemy's confidence/CL:條|条[tiao2]
to throw one's life in for/to haplessly give one's life for/to sacrifice oneself torturously working for another or for a group/to pour in one's utmost effort/to shed one's last ounce of strength for
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to fight back/to return fire/to counterattack
to contend on strong grounds/to argue strongly for what is right
to submit to humiliation (idiom); to suffer in silence/to swallow one's anger/to grin and bear it
to be determined to win (idiom)
to watch with folded arms (idiom); to look on without lifting a finger
to call loudly (idiom); to get people's attention/to make one's views known
to massacre one another (idiom); internecine strife
seize every minute and second (idiom); not a minute to lose/every moment counts
gongs and drums overture to a Chinese opera/to create a disturbance
dumbstruck and unable to reply (idiom); left speechless/at a loss for words
to send (sb) away/to change the subject/to open (an umbrella etc)
open the net on one side (idiom); let the caged bird fly/to give one's opponent a way out/lenient treatment
